theorem.title: Increasing/Decreasing
theorem.statement: Let f be a differentiable function on the interval (a,b). If f'(x) \gt 0 on (a,b), then f is increasing on (a,b). If f'(x) \lt 0 on (a,b), then f is decreasing on (a,b).

subsubsection.title: Local Extrema
subsubsection.p: Fermat's Theorem tells us that if we have a local max or min at input x = c, then c is a critical number of f. We need some more machinery in order to classify extrema.

theorem.title: First Derivative Test
theorem.statement: Suppose that c is a critical number of a continuous function f. If f' changes from positive to negative at c, then f has a local maximum at c. If f' changes from negative to positive at c, then f has a local minimum at c. If f' does not change sign around c, then f has no local maximum or minimum at c.

subsubsection.title: Concavity
subsubsection.p: The first derivative tells us information about where a function is increasing or decreasing, and where it has horizontal tangent lines. The second derivative tells us information about how a function bends.

definition.title: Concave Up/Concave Down
definition.p: If the graph of f lies above all of its tangents on an interval I, then it is said to be concave up on I; if f lies below all of its tangents on I, then it is said to be concave down on I.

definition.title: Inflection Point
definition.p: A point P on a curve y = f(x) is called an inflection point if f is continuous there and the curve changes concavity.

theorem.title: Concavity Test
theorem.statement: If f''(x) \gt 0 for all x in I, then the graph of f is concave up on I. If f''(x) \lt 0 for all x in I, then the graph of f is concave down on I

theorem.title: Second Derivative Test
theorem.p: Suppose f'' is continuous near c, and f'(c) = 0. If f''(c) \gt 0, then f has a local minimum at c. If f''(c) \lt 0, then f has a local maximum at c.
